Award.AwardTitle: Applications of Field Theory to Condensed Matter Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research aimed at understanding condensed matter systems involving many coupled degrees of freedom whose behavior is governed by strong effects of quantum mechanics, in particular strong interactions between electrons. Such understanding could lead to the prediction of new states of matter with novel properties as well as new materials with potentially useful applications.

A particular state of strongly interacting electrons originally predicted by the PI and his collaborators emerges in the so-called electronic liquid crystal phase, which is a quantum mechanical analogue of molecules found in liquid crystal displays, sharing properties of both a solid and a liquid. The PI will further investigate whether such phases can explain the peculiar properties of materials known as high temperature superconductors. At sufficiently low temperatures, electrons in superconductors enter a cooperative quantum mechanical state that enables them to conduct electricity without any resistance. High temperature superconductors are interesting because they exhibit superconductivity at much higher temperatures than many other known classes of superconductors. The PI's proposed state of matter may help explain how this is possible and how materials that exhibit superconductivity at room temperatures might be discovered. This could lead to virtually lossless transmission of electric power and other energy-related applications. The other focus of the research concerns the understanding of experiments seeking new states of matter, in particular the so-called topological states, which are predicted to have unusual properties that would enable computation based on the laws of quantum mechanics. Such a computer could solve certain problems much faster than any currently existing computer.

The research engages cutting edge problems in the physics of materials and provides excellent opportunities to train the next generation of theoretical scientists. Research and education will be further integrated through the development of advanced curricular materials. It also opens new possibilities for future technologies related to advanced solid-state materials for electronic devices.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project provides support for research into the theory of condensed matter systems involving many strongly coupled degrees of freedom whose behavior is governed by strong effects of quantum mechanics. The electrons in such strongly correlated systems organize spontaneously in electronic liquid crystal phases and topological phases. An unavoidable feature of these phases is that they naturally describe intertwined orders. The main projects focus on the theory of intertwined orders in strongly correlated systems and on topological phases of matter. Both lines of research require the development of new and transformative theoretical insights and the use of methods and ideas of quantum field theory. The particular topics that will be investigated include the relation between electronic liquid crystal phases and high temperature superconductivity, quantum coherence and interference phenomena in quantum Hall systems, quantum entanglement and topological quantum computing.

The research engages cutting edge problems in the physics of materials and provides excellent opportunities to train the next generation of theoretical scientists. Research and education will be further integrated through the development of advanced curricular materials. It also opens new possibilities for future technologies related to advanced solid-state materials for electronic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant suppprted research on two fundamental problems in Condensed Matter Physics: a) Intertwined Orders in High Temperature Superconductors and b) Topological Phases of Matter.

This project provided support for research into the theory of condensed matter. The objective is to understand condensed-matter systems involving many strongly coupled degrees of freedom whose behavior is governed by strong effects of quantum mechanics. The electrons in such strongly correlated systems self-organize in remarkable states of matter such as high temperature superconductors and topological phases of matter. This is a frontier area of research in which the understanding of some of the most fundamental problems in physics is achieved by experiments done at the cutting edge of technology. The nature of these problems requires the use of the methods and ideas of quantum field theory. Such an approach enables the project to exploit the continuing and mutually enriching cross-fertilization of ideas between condensed matter systems, high energy physics, and mathematics.

 

The research of the PI with his collaborators and students has revealed that high temperature superconducting states, a fundamental problem in physics which already has had a strong impact in technology,  are intimately related with other ordered states of matter which arise with equal strength. This fact is revealed in the complex nature of the phase diagrams of these systems. To understand these complex phenomena the PI and his coworkers have formulated the concept of intertwined orders. A major development during this past funding period was the development of a theory of intertwined orders and its consequences for experiment. At the root of these phenomena is the fact that high temperature superconductors originate from strong local interactions among the electrons and that states that are locally similar can appear either as homogenous macroscopic states or in non-uniform and/or anisotropic states. An example are the electronic nematic phases which were predicted by the PI and his coworkers some 20 years ago, which have now been discovered to exist in a wide class of different physics systems.

 

A remarkable example of intertwined orders is the pair-density wave superconducting state that the PI proposed as the explanation of the behavior of some high temperature superconductor. In this novel superconducting state superconductivity coexists (rather than compete) with charge and spin stripe orders. During the past funding period we made significant progress in understanding the physical origin of these states.

 

Topological phases are quantum fluid states of matter that do not have an order parameter, and therefore do not break any symmetry, but possess a kind of hidden quantum order in which the ground state degeneracy is determined by the topology of the space in which they live. The quantum states of a topological fluid exhibit large scale quantum entanglement, a key property to devise a topological quantum computer. This is a frontier problem in physics, mathematics, and computing technology.

 

The best understood example of a topological phase of matter are the fractional quantum Hall fluids. These fluids exist in electronic systems artificially confined to two dimensions and are subject to an external strong magnetic field. In these conditions, when the electronic system is subject to an in-plane electric field, an electrical current (the Hall current) perpendicular to both fields flows without dissipation. The behavior of this remarkable quantum fluid is characterized by a set of quantum numbers which are universal in the sense that they do not change under microscopic changes of the physical system. It turns out that this remarkable robustness is traced to the fact that these quantum numbers are characterized by a set of topological invariants, mathematically related to the theory of knots. Interest is these topological fluids has been rekindled after it was realized that some of them may be used as possible platforms for topological quantum computers.

 

A major new result we obtained during the past funding period is complete theory that describes how quantum Hall fluids relate to the geometric properties of the two-dimensional surface on which they reside. These investigations also revealed that, in addition of being topological fluids, quantum Hall states may also exhibit nematic ordered states in which the electronic fluid becomes spatially anisotropic.
